posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked: So our team has been using 6 gauge power wire for a while now, and we are now thinking about switching to 4 gauge because of the lesser resistance and the fact that most of the best bots in our district use 4 gauge or smaller. Can anyone list the pros and cons of these two power wires?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
We switched from 6 to 4 awg for batteries this year, after noticing that the 6 awg would be pretty warm, when swapping batteries.   We also minimized cable length: our battery cables are only about four inches long, and one of the cables to the PDP is only one inch long.  We haven’t systematically measured the electrical impact of this work, but we haven’t noticed the same “warm wires” problem either.  The main “con” is that there is some work to get the 4 awg into the Anderson terminals, but it’s doable.

One thing we have noticed is that long runs of 12 awg really do have a measurable impact: our algae shooting motor is on the end of about 8 feet of wire, and it briefly pulls the maximum available current.  When that happens, the controller reports about one volt less than the RIO sees, so we’re dissipating something like 60 W in the wires.   Briefly.

posts.name: Isaac Mendoza
posts.cooked: Do you guys put 4 gauge wire into sb50’s or sb120’s? Also I am also concerned about the price of changing to 4 gauge, how was that change for you guys?

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: We use SB50, just because we have so many of them, and like I said, it’s not great, cheating to get the larger wire into the terminal intended for 6 gauge.  If we were starting from scratch, then SB120 would be the correct choice.  The cost of the wire itself is a complete non-issue, as I mentioned we hardly use any length.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked:
Isaac2:

Do you guys put 4 gauge wire into sb50’s or sb120’s? Also I am also concerned about the price of changing to 4 gauge, how was that change for you guys?

If you’re moving to 4ga wire you’ll want to use SB120s because the SB50 has a maximum wire size of 6ga.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
We switched from 6 to 4 AWG a couple years ago, and SB120’s.  It helps a little with your voltage drop.  It’s hard to quantify it, but if you’re routinely pulling over 200A then it might be worth it.  Only do it if you’re in the phase of looking for tiny improvements and you’re willing to throw a bit of money and time at it.

Remember you have to purchase some adapters too.  These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging your batteries into existing battery chargers.  It all adds up.

In addition to the extra cost, we’ve found that it’s harder for the students (and honestly for the mentors too) when unplugging the SB120 connectors.  You may beat up your knuckles a bit more if you have metal corners nearby.

link_counts.title: SB120 to SB50 Battery Adapter Cable - AndyMark, Inc

posts.name: Michael Tucker
posts.cooked:
With the amp hungry devices in use now (Kraken, Vortex), anything you can do to lower the current pathway resistance from battery to end device is worth the effort.

Evaluate everything, including PDP / PDH devices and let the data inform your decision.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked:
Programming4907:

Remember you have to purchase some adapters too. These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging your batteries into existing battery chargers.

You can also just make adapters yourself, which is cheaper than buying them from Andymark, especially if you have SB50s just sitting around. Use very short 6ga wires between the SB50 and SB120 connectors (about 2"-3" works fine.) That’s what we did and they work just fine for these purposes.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Programming4907:

Remember you have to purchase some adapters too. These are for plugging into old robots, lending batteries to other teams, and plugging your batteries into existing battery chargers. It all adds up.

You can, of course, make your own adapters (for a bit less $). Another considerations is that crimping 4AWG can be a real challenge for some of your smaller team members.

In addition to the extra cost, we’ve found that it’s harder for the students (and honestly for the mentors too) when unplugging the SB120 connectors. You may beat up your knuckles a bit more if you have metal corners nearby.  And be sure to get flexible 4AWG or you will have so much fun with it.

On the plus side, we no longer have to ziptie the SB120’s together like we did the SB50’s lest they come apart in competition.

Why are you considering switching? Are you having issues with brownouts or other battery related issues?

In my experience the only time switching from 6awg to 4awg will solve your problems is if your current battery leads have bad crimps or bad connections (in which case just redoing what you already have will also fix the issue). Any other problems are usually not solved by switching. The difference in resistance will be close to negligible for such a short run. For reference at my work we don’t even bother calculating for resistance of wire until our runs are over 10ft. You’d probably get similar benefit from making your current battery leads shorter if they are really long.

If you are having issues I’d recommend setting some current limits in the code, ramp up for acceleration, run less motors or smaller motors if possible, and check all your wiring for good connections.

It doesn’t hurt anything to switch, so if you are one of those edge cases where it might make a difference to get that little bit extra then go for it. Only other advice if you are going to switch is to get some high flex welding type wire so they are easier to work with.

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked:
mtuckerFRC4381:

With the amp hungry devices in use now (Kraken, Vortex), anything you can do to lower the current pathway resistance from battery to end device is worth the effort.

Not if that same effort or cost can get you greater gains elsewhere.  Upgrading your power cables is a very small difference.  If you’re struggling to afford a vision system or a gyro, or you don’t have time to tweak your autos, then spending time and money upgrading battery cables is an inefficient use of your resources.

posts.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
posts.cooked: Last I checked it is likely on a couple tenths of volts at 250+ amps saved.  It seemed helpful last year but this year’s game we at least haven’t pushed batteries as hard.  Depends on robot I guess.  But it is a marginal gain compared to having good crimps and properly tightening everything.  And maintaining good batteries.
posts.display_username: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)

posts.name: Matt Middleton
posts.cooked: We switched over the offseason for a few reasons - not all related to performance / resistance.  Be ready for some sticker shock with re-kitting with SB-120’s.  Those puppies will set you back a good chunk of coin.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked:
Programming4907:

Not if that same effort or cost can get you greater gains elsewhere.

True. Switching to 4AWG, in addition to the time (ideally you are doing this in the summer), wil cost you approximately

$17 per SB120,

$2 per foot of wire,

$2 per copper lug,

and probably at least $35 for a good high-leverage crimping tool,

and if you’re doing this, you probably should be using the grasshopper connectors $8/battery.

So to do a dozen batteries, 1 charger, and 1 robot could cost you over $500 – maybe: (16 x $17) + (30 x $2) + (24 x $2) + $35 + (12 x $8)

[edit: forgot the lugs]

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
truher:

We also minimized cable length

Just want to highlight this. Figuring out how to make your  leads really, really short will generally give you as much gain as going to a smaller gauge. We do use 4AWG/SB120s for the marginal gain, but putting your battery, main breaker, and PDP all right next to each other will generally make a bigger difference.

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked:
Might be a hot take, but aside from lacking 4ga SB50 wire contacts, I have no concerns with using an SB50 with 4ga wire in our application. In my pit wanderings this year, I was checking it out and as I saw, estimate that for the teams using 4ga wire, 80% used SB50, 20% used SB120. The only annoying thing is that the largest manufacturer SB50 lug is 6ga.

For those concerned (“what about the 50 in SB50?”) check out https://www.andersonpower.com/content/dam/app/ecommerce/product-pdfs/SB50/ds-sb50.pdf , among other things their UL 1977 rating is 120A (granted it’s hot plug rating is 50A, but no one is hot plugging the bot, and even then it could’t give an instant 50A load). It’s common practice smaller wire than full size in devices because they take into account the loading and heat dissipation characteristics of their device. Our SB50 and 4ga wires are in free air, and as we observed in our bot, not seeing excessive heat increases.

For that annoying bit about lack of 4ga lugs, you can expand the 6ga lugs, trim strands (I hear the pearl clutching), try do to some clever(silly?) things with 4ga-6ga adapters. For expanding, I found a few steel rods with appropirate shaping on the contact end along with lubricant does the job, but it’s slow. If someone has a nice answer for this please share.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: 2363 has a white paper on expanding the 6 awg lugs: https://team2363.org/2017/05/using-4-awg-with-the-anderson-sb50/

link_counts.title: Using 4 AWG cable with the Anderson SB50 connectors – Triple Helix Robotics

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: I would go better than the $35 crimp tool, and get something hydraulic. We went with the TEMCo TH0006 with was ~$150 and I appreciate that it came with half size dies which saved me a few times when hitting nonstandard lugs. I hear the harbor freight one is popular at ~$70 (and there’s usually some kind of deal going at HF especially if you have other things to get).

posts.name: Dave Morrison
posts.cooked: Nice, thanks!

posts.name: Cosimo Aho
posts.cooked:
My team (4973) is also switching from 6-gauge to 4-gauge (copper), to hopefully some reduce voltage drop under load. Our current robot is equipped with Kraken X60s & Falcon 500s, for reference we experience transients that bring the load to about ~175A.  We have not actually had time to implement it yet, but the price difference was pretty negligible - I think maybe $10 more per wire?  Very small compared to costs like the PDH , roboRIO, etc. Keep in mind you will have to buy new crimps & Anderson connectors that will accept the 4-gauge.

At 26 inches of length, this is the difference in electrical resistance between the two: 6-gauge: Resistance = 0.8363 mQ, Conductance 1.1958 kS, Diameter = 4.11 mm 4-gauge: Resistance = 0.5244 mQ, Conductance 1.907 kS, Diameter = 5.19 mm

So in short the 4 gauge cable is about 60 more conductive than the 6 gauge one, for less than double the price. Should reduce some voltage drop.
